An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Does the concept of a/an Algebraic closure of a field need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an algebraic subset involves the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\), where \(\bar{K}\) is the algebraic closure of a field \(K\). This definition inherently uses the concept of an algebraic closure of a field, as it specifies that the zeros are to be found in \(\bar{K}^{n}\), indicating that the elements of the subset are within the algebraic closure of \(K\). Without the concept of an algebraic closure, the space \(\bar{K}^{n}\) in which these zeros are considered would not be well-defined, making the definition of an algebraic subset incomplete or nonsensical. Therefore, the concept of an algebraic closure of a field is necessary for the definition of an algebraic subset to be meaningful and complete.
